Tuning the interaction between Cu and surface -OH in Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalyst for enhanced semi-hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate Xiaodan Shi Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Data curation Peipei Ai Writing – review & editing Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Yu Zhang Investigation Data curation Jiangtao Zhao Validation Investigation Wei Huang Supervision Resources Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, Shanxi, China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan Shanxi 030024 China State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, Shanxi, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Methyl glycolate (MG), a crucial chemical raw material and fine chemical intermediate, holds immense potential in the production of the next-generation biodegradable material, polyglycolic acid, via polycondensation reactions. In this study, layered Ti3C2 MXene was used as support precursor to construct Cu based catalysts for the semi-hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to MG. By fine-tuning the loading method of Cu species, the interaction between Cu species and surface hydroxyl groups (-OH) was modulated, and the effect on the semi-hydrogenation performance of Cu-based catalysts were thereby explored. These catalysts underwent rigorous characterization using BET, SEM-EDS, XRD, FT-IR, H2-TPR and XPS techniques. The results revealed that varying loading methods significantly influenced the interaction between Cu species and surface -OH on Ti3C2 MXene during preparation process, altering the content of Ti-O-Cu as well as the Cu0 ratio of Cu/Ti3C2-derived catalysts. The Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst displayed remarkable performance, achieving a MG selectivity of 88.85 % and stability of up to 120 h in the DMO hydrogenation reaction due to its high Cu0 ratio and large Cu particles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ti3C2MXene Hydrogenation Cu catalyst Methyl glycolate Interaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Methyl glycolate (MG) is rich in functional groups, endowing it with the chemical properties of both esters and alcohols due to its ester and hydroxyl groups. As a crucial chemical raw material and fine chemical intermediate, MG is utilized in the production of the next-generation biodegradable material, polyglycolic acid (PGA), through polycondensation reactions [1]. Notably, the industrial application of synthesizing MG from the semi-hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) through syngas has commenced, standing out from other preparation processes [2,3]. Given China's resource abundance in coal but scarcity in oil and gas, the process of coal-based syngas to produce MG via DMO semi-hydrogenation aligns perfectly with the green development concept and possesses significant economic value. The DMO hydrogenation reaction is a sequential process where DMO undergoes semi-hydrogenation to yield MG, which then undergoes further hydrogenation to produce ethylene glycol (EG) and ethanol (EtOH). Due to the thermodynamic constants of DMO hydrogenation to produce EG being much higher than those of MG, it is difficult to control the DMO hydrogenation products to stay on MG [4,5]. Currently, Ag-based and Cu-based catalysts are widely used in the synthesis of MG through DMO semi-hydrogenation. Ag-based catalysts exhibit a relatively weak hydrogenation activity, and the yield of DMO hydrogenation to produce MG can reach up to 95 % [6–8]. However, the limited availability and high cost of Ag hinder its large-scale application [9]. Conversely, Cu-based catalysts, due to their low cost and high hydrogenation activity, have garnered significant attention from domestic and international companies as well as research institutions [10]. Nonetheless, a key challenge in using Cu catalysts is the precise control of the DMO hydrogenation depth [11]. High temperatures tend to promote deep hydrogenation of MG, resulting in low selectivity, while lower temperatures compromise the DMO conversion. Therefore, developing a stable Cu-based catalyst with high MG yield is the key to the synthesis of MG from coal-based syngas via DMO semi-hydrogenation. MXene, a novel two-dimensional material, comprises transition metal carbides or carbon nitrides [12]. Through a chemical liquid phase method, the A element in the MAX phase can be selectively etched to obtain the corresponding MXene. The surface of MXene is adorned with an array of adjustable functional groups, whose types are influenced by the choice of etching agent or reprocessing technique. Intriguingly, the -OH functional group present on the surface of MXene interacts with the supported metal Cu via the formation of Ti-O-Cu bonds. Notably, the amount of Ti-O-Cu bonds can be tuned by modulating the interaction between the surface -OH functional groups of MXene and Cu species, enabling precise control over the Cu valence composition. A study by Zu et al. [13] examined the self-catalytic decomposition of Cu-EDTA during the Ti3C2T x MXene/peroxymonosulfate process, which revealed that the released free Cu2+ ions form Ti-O-Cu bonds with Ti3C2Tx MXene, accelerating electron transfer from Ti3C2T x to Cu2+ and ultimately yielding Cu+. Yen et al. [14] synthesized Cu-doped Ti3C2T x MXene and confirmed that the MXene effectively reduced Cu2+ to near +1 valence state via forming Ti-O-Cu bonds. In addition, the unique layered structure of MXene not only enhances the exposure of supported metal, but also enables rapid transfer of reactants and products [15,16]. Under thermal treatment, MXene tends to convert into more stable metal oxide composites. The unique two-dimensional structure and abundant hydroxyl group on the surface make MXene an excellent support precursor for dispersing and regulating metal active sites [17]. Consequently, the utilization of Ti3C2Tx MXene as a support precursor for derived Cu-based catalysts presents a promising approach for optimizing the semi-hydrogenation performance of Cu-based catalysts. In this paper, Ti3C2 MXene was utilized as a support precursor for fabricating Cu-based catalysts, which were then harnessed in the semi-hydrogenation of DMO to MG. The interaction between the Cu species and the Ti3C2 MXene precursor could significantly affect the particle size and chemical valence state of the loaded Cu species of derived catalyst, thereby influencing their catalytic activity and stability. Therefore, this work explores the modulation of the metal-support interaction through variations in the loading process. A comprehensive suite of characterization techniques, including XRD, FT-IR, SEM, BET, XPS and H2-TPR, was employed to systematically analyze the physicochemical properties, Cu particle size, and valence composition of Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived Cu-based catalysts prepared under diverse loading conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and characterizations Aluminum titanium carbide (Ti3AlC2), hydrofluoric acid (HF), copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O) and potassium bromide (KBr) were ready for use without further purification. The XRD patterns of the catalysts were characterized using a Rigaku D/max-2500 X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα-ray source (λ=0.15406 nm). This analysis was performed within a scanning range of 5°−80° and a rate of 8°/min. FT-IR characterization of the support was performed using a Themmo Is10 infrared spectrometer manufactured by Thermo Fisher. The KBr used for tablet pressing was dried in an oven at 150 °C overnight to remove the water and prevent the influence on the testing process. Subsequently, 0.1 g of dried KBr and a precise amount of samples were put into a mortar for homogeneous mixing and grinding, and pressed into a transparent sheet under the condition of 10 MPa for 1 min. The sheet was then inserted into the infrared spectrometer and scanned 32 times in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The SEM was utilized the ZEISS Geimi 300 scanning electron microscope, manufactured by Zeiss in Germany, and the EDS spectrometer was used for electrochemical data system mapping testing. The specific surface area and pore structure of the samples were characterized using a QDS-30 physical adsorbent meter from Kantar Instruments, USA. A certain amount of sample was weighed in a sample tube, heated up to 200 °C and degassed for 4 h, and then the adsorption/desorption experiments were carried out at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (−196 °C). The catalyst-related fabrication parameters (specific surface area, pore size, pore volume, etc.) were measured by BET and BJH methods. XPS characterization was tested using a Thermo ESCALAB 250XL energy spectrometer with Al kα radiation (hv=1486.6 eV), and binding energies were calculated with C 1s (284.6 eV) with a measurement error of ±0.05 eV The H2-TPR characterization was tested by a TP-5000 (Xian Quan, Tianjin) multi-purpose adsorption instrument. The test tube containing 0.05 g catalyst was heated up to 150 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere and pretreated for 60 min. Following this, the temperature was gradually lowered to 50 °C, and the nitrogen was purged for 30 min and then switched to 10 % H2/Ar gas (30 mL/min) for analysis with a temperature increase rate of 10 °C/min. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of Ti3C2 MXene support precursor Ti3C2 was prepared by wet etching method using Ti3AlC2 powder, in which the etching solution was hydrofluoric acid. Typically, 2 g of Ti3AlC2 powder was added to 20 mL of hydrofluoric acid solution and reactively etched at room temperature for 24 h. In order to avoid violent exotherm, Ti3AlC2 powder needs to be added slowly. After the etching reaction, the resulting suspension was washed with deionized water and centrifuged several times until the pH was closed to neutral. Finally, the precipitate was dried in a vacuum drying oven at 80 °C overnight to eliminate additional water molecules. The reaction equation is as follows: 2Ti3AlC2+6HF=2Ti3C2+2AlF3+3H2. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts The Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst with 10 % Cu planned loading was prepared using ultrasound-assisted impregnation. 0.5 mL water solution containing 0.42 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was added drop by drop to 1.0 g of Ti3C2 MXene support precursor with the aid of ultrasound, followed by vacuum aging of the sample for 3 h at room temperature and vacuum drying at 80 °C overnight. The dried sample was calcined in a tube furnace at a rate of 2 °C/min for 4 h at 400 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. Finally, the sample after calcination was named as Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I. The process of Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W catalyst with 10 % Cu planned loading prepared by wet impregnation was as follows. Firstly, 1 g Ti3C2 MXene support precursor was evenly dispersed in 5 mL deionized water. Secondly, 0.42 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was added into the solution and stirred. The resulting mixture was then left to dry overnight at 80 °C. After drying, the sample was calcined in a tube furnace at a rate of 2 °C/min for 4 h at 400 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. Finally, the sample after calcination was named as Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W. 2.3 Catalyst activity test The DMO hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a quartz tube fixed-bed reactor (Fig. S1 ) with an inner diameter of 6 mm, and 0.4 g of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was placed in the constant temperature zone at the upper end of the quartz tube indentation. The catalyst was first pre-reduced at 300 °C under H2 atmosphere for 3 h. Afterwards, the reactor temperature was adjusted to the reaction temperature, the reactor pressure was increased to 2.5 MPa, and the feedstock liquid was fed into the reactor by a high-pressure infusion pump. The liquid phase products were condensed by a low-temperature circulating cooling pump and then analyzed by Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatography with FID detector and DB-624 capillary column. According to the GC spectra (Fig. S2), the products were quantitatively analyzed by internal standard method with isopropanol as internal standard, and the catalytic performance of the catalyst was measured by DMO conversion and product selectivity. The conversion and selectivity can be calculated from the following equations: (1) X DMO = n i n , DMO − n o u t , DMO n i n , DMO × 100 (2) S i = n i n i , D M O × 100 % X DMO—-DMO conversion, %; nin, DMO—-The amount of DMO in the feedstock liquid, mol; nout, DMO—-The amount of DMO in the product, mol; Si-—Selectivity of product i; ni —-The amount of product i, mol; ni, DMO—-Total amount of DMO converted. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Ti3C2 MXene support precursor and Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts 3.1.1 Characterization of Ti3C2 MXene support precursor The Ti3C2 MXene support precursor was successfully synthesized through the HF etching of Ti3AlC2. To gain a comprehensive understanding of the etching outcome, various analytical techniques were employed, including XRD, FT-IR, XPS and SEM, to delve into its physical phase composition and structural properties. Fig. 1a showed the XRD patterns of raw Ti3AlC2 and the resulting Ti3C2 MXene. The strong diffraction peak of Ti3AlC2 located at 2θ=39° was related to the Ti-Al bond of the (104) crystal plane. After HF etching, this peak disappeared, and the diffraction peaks appeared at 2θ=8.65°, 18.10°, 27.30° and 61.00° corresponded to the (002), (004), (006), and (110) crystal planes of Ti3C2 MXene, respectively. This result unequivocally demonstrated that the HF etching process effectively removed the Al component. Furthermore, the diffraction peak (002) of Ti3C2 MXene was shifted to the low angle after etching, indicating an expansion in the interlayer spacing [18]. To delve deeper into the surface functional groups, FT-IR analysis was conducted, as depicted in Fig. 1b. The stretching vibrational band of -OH groups observed at 3440 and 1627 cm−1 were assigned to the absorbed external water and strongly hydrogen-bonded OH or extremely strong coordinated H2O on the Ti3C2 MXene surface. The peaks at 1384, 1064 and 848 cm−1 may be attributed to the bending vibration of OH bond, a stretching vibration of C-F bond and deformation vibration of Ti-O-Ti linkage, respectively [19,20]. Combining the XRD and FT-IR data, it is evident that the HF etching process not only successfully removed the Al component from Ti3AlC2 but also introduced surface-terminated -OH functional group. This introduction of -OH groups is crucial as it facilitates the formation of Ti-O-Cu bonds with Cu. The XPS analysis revealed the distinct surface composition of the Ti3C2 MXene. Specifically, the Ti3C2 MXene, achieved through HF etching, was primarily comprised of Ti, C, O, and F, as shown in Fig. 2a. Notably, the absence of the Al element in the XPS survey spectrum of Ti3C2 MXene indicated a successful etching of Ti3AlC2, which concurred with the XRD findings. HF etching of Ti3AlC2 effectively eliminated Al and enlarged the layer spacing. Additionally, as depicted in the SEM image of Fig. 2b, the Ti3C2 MXene exhibited a smooth accordion-like layered structure following the chemical etching of its Ti3AlC2 precursor. This layered structure of Ti3C2 MXene not only favored the dispersion of Cu species as a support precursor, but also fostered efficient transfer of reactants and products, enhancing the rapid desorption of MG and subsequently inhibiting its deep hydrogenation. 3.1.2 Characterization of Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts To modulate the metal-support interaction, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts were crafted through diverse loading processes. In order to investigate the effect of loading processes on the pore structure of catalysts, the support and catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption (Fig. 3 ). The detailed pore structure data were summarized in Table 1 . From the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms, it can be observed that both Ti3C2 MXene support precursor and Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts exhibited "IV" type isotherm with H3 type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of slit-shaped pores in the samples [21]. These pores originate from the formation of accordion-like stacks of Ti3C2 MXene nanosheet. Notably, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts showed an increase in both specific surface area and pore volume compared to the bare Ti3C2 MXene support precursor. This augmentation is likely attributed to the formation of TiO2 nanoparticles from smooth Ti3C2 during the thermal annealing process [22] and the growth of Cu nanoparticles on the support's surface [23]. Moreover, the average pore size of both catalysts tends to decrease, with a more significant reduction observed in the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W catalyst. This suggests a higher proportion of Cu infiltrating the pores, resulting in a smaller Cu particle size. To delve into the morphological features of the catalysts, SEM characterization of the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts was carried out. As evident from the SEM images presented in Fig. 4 , the pristine layered structure of Ti3C2 MXene was retained, while a distinct layer of Cu particles adhered to the surface of the MXene precursor. This observation was further validated by the notable enhancement in the specific surface area of catalysts after Cu loading. To investigate the physical phase composition of the catalysts, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts after calcination were characterized by XRD, as shown in Fig. 5 . Upon Cu species loading, the distinct diffraction peaks associated with Ti3C2 MXene underwent a near-total disappearance, and diffraction peaks corresponding to the TiO2 phase emerged in all catalysts. During the preparation process, Ti3C2 MXene could be oxidized by ambient oxygen, water and CuO to form TiO2 [14,23]. Moreover, pronounced Cu0 diffraction peaks emerged at 2θ of 43.20°, 50.30°, and 74.10°, which could plausibly be ascribed to the self-reduction of Cu species during the calcination process, which could be attributed to that the Ti3C2 MXene support precursor facilitated the reduction of loaded metal oxides to metals in their lower valence states as documented in prior studies [24–26]. Consequently, after calcination, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts exhibited Cu species in a lower valence state, alongside Ti species of higher valence, confirming that a redox reaction occurred between the loaded CuO species and the low-valent Ti species in the support during the calcination process. The particle size of the Cu species could be determined using the Scherrer formula, yielding values of 48.50 and 41.60 nm for the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I and Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W catalysts, respectively. To ascertain the chemical state of the Ti element, XPS testing was performed, with the Ti 2p peaks being subject to split-peak fitting. As can be seen from Fig. 6a, the peaks observed at 454.30 and 455.40 eV for the Ti3C2 MXene support precursor correspond to Ti (II) and Ti (III), respectively [25]. Upon analyzing the Ti 2p spectra of the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts, we observed the absence of the Ti (II) peak and a significant decrease in the relative content of Ti (III), dropping from 47.76 % in Ti3C2 MXene to 4.26 % in Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I and 9.18 % in Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W. Additionally, the peaks at 458.50 and 464.50 eV align with Ti (IV) 2p 3/2 and Ti (IV) 2p 1/2, respectively, which was consistent with the literature reporting on the Ti valence state of TiO2 [27,28]. The enhanced intensity of the Ti (IV) peaks further suggested that the valence state of Ti in the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts underwent a transition during the calcination process, due to the formation of TiO2. Combined the XRD and XPS analysis, we speculated that the appearance of low-valent Cu0/Cu+ species in the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts can be attributed to the conversion of Ti from a low-valent state to a high-valent state during the calcination process [24,28]. It has been reported in the literature that the -OH functional group on the Ti3C2 MXene surface interacts with the loaded Cu species, fostering the formation of Ti-O-Cu bonds, which enhances the Cu-support interaction. To quantify this bond formation, we delved into the Ti-O to Ti-OH ratio in the catalysts through meticulous analysis [29]. The XPS O 1s spectra (Fig. 6b) revealed peaks centered at 532.2 eV and 530.5 eV, corresponding to Ti-OH and Ti-O, respectively, in both Ti3C2 MXene and Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts [21,30,31]. The O 1s peak splitting results indicated a lower ratio of Ti-O to Ti-OH in the Ti3C2 MXene support precursor compared to the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts, confirming the formation of Ti-O-Cu bonds. Notably, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W catalyst exhibited a higher ratio of Ti-O to Ti-OH (2.32) than the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst (0.65). This finding suggested that the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst forms fewer Ti-O-Cu bonds on its surface, resulting in a weaker Cu-support interaction, which could be reflected by H2-TPR results. The interaction between Cu species and surface -OH groups in Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts profoundly impacted their catalytic performance. To elucidate the strength of this interaction derived from different loading methods, H2-TPR characterization of the catalysts was performed [32]. As shown in Fig. 7 , it is generally recognized that the low-temperature peak in the range of 220 °C is ascribed to the highly dispersed Cu species, while the high-temperature peak above 250 °C is attributed to large Cu species. the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst, prepared by ultrasound-assisted impregnation, exhibited a reduction peak at lower temperature, suggesting a feeble interaction between the Cu species and the support [33]. Conversely, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W catalyst, prepared by wet impregnation, showed reduction peak at higher temperature, indicating a stronger interaction between the Cu species and the support [34]. The adoption of different loading methods resulted in significant variations in the Cu dispersion and the metal-support interaction of the catalyst, ultimately influencing the valence composition of Cu and thus affecting the catalytic performance. To investigate the valence composition of Cu on the catalyst surface, XPS analysis was employed. In the Cu 2p spectrum (Fig. 6c), the diffraction peaks observed near 932.3 and 952.1 eV were identified as the characteristic peaks of Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2, respectively [35]. Notably, none of the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts exhibited satellite peaks between 941 and 945 eV indicative of Cu2+, suggesting that the Cu2+ in these catalysts had been reduced to lower valence states, namely Cu+ and/or Cu0. To gain a deeper understanding of the distribution of Cu across these two valence states, the Cu LMM spectrum (Fig. 6d) was dissected. The characteristic peaks at 913.5 and 917.1 eV were ascribed to Cu+and Cu0 species, respectively [36]. As depicted in Fig. 6d, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst boasted a significantly higher Cu0 ratio of 75.04 %, compared to the 58.13 % recorded for Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W. This disparity can be attributed to the interaction between Cu species and -OH groups on the support surface, which led to the formation of the difficult-to-reduce Ti-O-Cu species. Notably, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst, with a lower Ti-O-Cu generation, exhibited a higher Cu0 ratio. This underscores the influence of the Cu-support interaction on the valence distribution of Cu species on the catalyst surface. 3.2 Activity evaluation of Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts The DMO hydrogenation reaction is a tandem reaction. Initially, DMO undergoes partial hydrogenation to form MG, subsequently undergoing further hydrogenation to produce EG, and ultimately achieving deep hydrogenation to yield EtOH. Consequently, precise control over the depth of DMO hydrogenation is paramount in the synthesis of MG. To explore the impact of Cu-support interaction on Cu-based catalysts in regulating the DMO hydrogenation depth, we evaluated the catalytic performance of Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts under the reaction conditions of T = 200 °C, P = 2.5 MPa, WHSV=0.1 h−1 and n(H2)/n(DMO)=100. From the Fig. 8 , both catalysts primarily generated MG under the evaluated conditions, with the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst exhibiting a superior MG yield of 59.85 %, surpassing the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W catalyst (45.43 %). This finding suggested that the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst, prepared through ultrasound-assisted impregnation, was more adept at modulating the hydrogenation activity, thereby facilitating precise control over the DMO hydrogenation depth. H2-TPR and XPS characterizations revealed a notable interaction between the -OH functional group presented on the Ti3C2 MXene support precursor surface and the loaded Cu species, resulting in the formation of the Ti-O-Cu bond. This bond poses a challenge in terms of reduction, leading to an elevated proportion of Cu+ in the reduced catalyst. When comparing the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst with the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-W catalyst, the former exhibited a weaker interaction between the -OH functional group and the loaded Cu species, subsequently reducing the formation of the Ti-O-Cu bond. Consequently, after reduction, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst possessed a higher Cu0 ratio. In the DMO hydrogenation reaction, Cu0 and Cu+ species serve as complex active centers. Cu0 species facilitate the dissociation of H2 [37–40], while Cu+ species aid in dissociating methoxy groups and stabilizing acyl species [41]. Given that previous studies have emphasized the crucial role of Cu0 in the DMO hydrogenation to MG [42], a higher Cu0 ratio is favorable to produce the semi-hydrogenated product MG. Moreover, XRD analysis revealed that the Cu nanoparticles on the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst exhibited a larger particle size of 48.50 nm. Typically, large Cu particles tend to exhibit weaker hydrogenation activity. This, coupled with the high Cu0 ratio, contributes to the weak hydrogenation activity of the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst, ultimately resulting in a high yield of 59.85 % for the semi-hydrogenated product MG. Otherwise, reaction performance evaluations of the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst at various WHSV were conducted to study the effect of WHSV on MG production (Fig. 8b). When the WHSV was decreased from 0.2 h⁻¹ to 0.1 h⁻¹, the residence time of the reactants on the catalyst increased. This led to an improvement in the conversion rate from 54.59 % to 67.36 %. However, the hydrogenation depth changed minimally. Further decreasing the WHSV from 0.1 h⁻¹ to 0.05 h⁻¹ resulted in an even longer residence time, which enhanced the hydrogenation depth. Consequently, the selectivity for MG decreased significantly from 88.85 % to 35.18 %. This decrease in MG selectivity was accompanied by an increase in the production of EG and EtOH. Therefore, the retention of MG on the catalyst significantly influenced hydrogenation depth and MG selectivity. The stability of a catalyst serves as a pivotal indicator of its overall catalytic performance. In the case of the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst, its stability was rigorously evaluated at a temperature of 200 °C, demonstrating remarkable resilience as it maintained its stability for an extended duration of 120 h, as illustrated in Fig. 9 . 4 Conclusions In this study, Cu/Ti3C2 MXene derived catalysts were efficiently synthesized using different loading techniques, specifically for the hydrogenation of DMO to yield MG. These methods effectively modulated the dispersion of Cu and its interaction with the surface -OH groups of the Ti3C2 MXene support precursor. Detailed H2-TPR and XPS analysis unveiled a prominent interaction between the -OH functional group residing on the surface of Ti3C2 MXene support precursor and the loaded Cu species. This interaction facilitated the formation of the Ti-O-Cu bond, thereby elevating the proportion of Cu+ in the catalyst. Notably, the Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst, prepared via ultrasonic-assisted impregnation, exhibited larger Cu particle sizes and a higher Cu0/(Cu0+Cu+) ratio. This unique structure favored the inhibition of excessive hydrogenation of MG, ultimately leading to an improved MG selectivity. At a temperature of 200 °C, the catalyst achieved a MG selectivity of 88.85 % and stability up to 120 h. This research offers a novel approach for the development of Cu-based catalysts in the hydrogenation of DMO to MG. coredata.dc:description: Methyl glycolate (MG), a crucial chemical raw material and fine chemical intermediate, holds immense potential in the production of the next-generation biodegradable material, polyglycolic acid, via polycondensation reactions. In this study, layered Ti3C2 MXene was used as support precursor to construct Cu based catalysts for the semi-hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate to MG. By fine-tuning the loading method of Cu species, the interaction between Cu species and surface hydroxyl groups (-OH) was modulated, and the effect on the semi-hydrogenation performance of Cu-based catalysts were thereby explored. These catalysts underwent rigorous characterization using BET, SEM-EDS, XRD, FT-IR, H2-TPR and XPS techniques. The results revealed that varying loading methods significantly influenced the interaction between Cu species and surface -OH on Ti3C2 MXene during preparation process, altering the content of Ti-O-Cu as well as the Cu0 ratio of Cu/Ti3C2-derived catalysts. The Cu/Ti3C2 MXene-I catalyst displayed remarkable performance, achieving a MG selectivity of 88.85 % and stability of up to 120 h in the DMO hydrogenation reaction due to its high Cu0 ratio and large Cu particles.
